page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY NOTES.
page.content: The earliest reference to the village is in the Domesday Book,where Haslingefeld appears as the largest township in the Hundred of Wetherley, with a population of about 400.But there is archaeological evidence that people were moving up the river from the fens and living here over 3,000 years ago.Flint daggers and pottery of the late Stone Age have been found, probably left by passing campers engaged in fishing and fowling;weaving implements,coins and harness relics of the Iron Age are signs of an early farming settlement. The most interesting 'find' has been the pre-Christian Anglo-Saxon cemetery accidentally uncovered along the Cantelupe Road by coprolite diggers in the 1870s.There was no archaeologist at hand to record the findings or restrain the workmen from
